content: The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" expands the definition of a homeless veteran for benefits under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Section 2002(1) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include subsection (a) or (b) of section 103 of the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act. Additionally, a program is established to provide intensive case management interventions to homeless veterans who receive the most health care from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary shall provide intensive case management interventions to covered veterans enrolled in the homeless registry and annual patient enrollment system. The Secretary will implement a program for homeless veterans at six selected locations, including cities with high homeless veteran populations and suburban/rural settings. The Secretary will select three locations in suburban or rural settings with high homeless veteran populations for a program providing housing and social services. The Secretary will provide intensive case management interventions to covered veterans at selected locations, focusing on those who receive the most health care services. Assistance will include outreach, employment, and financial aid for homeless, at-risk, and low-income veterans. The Secretary will provide intensive case management interventions to covered veterans at selected locations to improve housing stability and access to healthcare services. The Secretary will provide intensive case management interventions to covered veterans at selected locations to improve housing stability and access to healthcare services, as necessary to improve the stability of their housing and the appropriateness of the health care they receive. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement intensive case management interventions for covered veterans to enhance housing stability and healthcare access. The program must commence by September 1, 2016, with a report due by December 1, 2018 to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The report to be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs will include assessments of the types and frequencies of intensive case management interventions provided, the housing status, and the employment status of veterans who received these interventions. The report will include assessments of intensive case management interventions provided to veterans, their housing status, employment status before and after receiving interventions, and the use of health care services by veterans. The report will assess the use of intensive case management interventions by veterans, including the number of veterans who received these interventions and the costs incurred by the Department of Veterans Affairs for providing care and services before and after the interventions. The report will evaluate the use of intensive case management interventions by veterans, including the number of veterans who received these interventions and the costs incurred by the Department of Veterans Affairs for providing care and services before and after the interventions, disaggregated by location. The report will evaluate the costs incurred by the Department in carrying out the program, including the provision of intensive case management interventions in specific locations. It will also estimate the costs that would have been incurred for health care and associated services to covered veterans if not for the intensive case management interventions. The report will evaluate costs incurred by the Department for providing intensive case management interventions in specific locations and estimate the costs that would have been incurred for health care and associated services to covered veterans without these interventions. Program to improve retention of housing by formerly homeless veterans and veterans at risk of becoming homeless. The Secretary is required to implement a program providing case management services to help veterans retain housing after experiencing homelessness or being at risk of homelessness. The Secretary must implement a program offering case management services to support homeless veterans transitioning to permanent housing and veterans at risk of homelessness through grants prioritizing organizations with the capability to provide such services. The Secretary will award grants to organizations prioritizing those with the capability to provide case management services for homeless veterans transitioning to permanent housing or at risk of homelessness. Extra priority will be given to organizations that voluntarily stop receiving funding from specific sections. The Secretary will prioritize organizations that can provide case management services for homeless veterans transitioning to permanent housing or at risk of homelessness. Extra priority will be given to organizations that voluntarily stop receiving funding and convert transitional housing facilities into permanent housing that meets quality standards. The organization will convert transitional housing facilities into permanent housing that meets quality standards established under the United States Housing Act of 1937. Such conversions will not be considered non-compliance with grant terms. The organization's conversion of transitional housing facilities into permanent housing, meeting quality standards under the United States Housing Act of 1937, will not be considered non-compliance with grant terms. Subparagraph (B)(ii) specifies that such conversion is deemed to be in line with Department needs. A clerical amendment updates the table of sections in chapter 20 of the title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will prescribe regulations to improve housing retention for formerly homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Authorization of appropriations is granted. A report must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs by June 1, 2019. The Secretary must submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs by June 1, 2019, regarding the program's effectiveness in helping veterans retain permanent housing. The report must include assessments of the percentage of veterans who received case management services under the program and their housing status at the end of the pilot program. The report must include assessments of veterans who received case management services under the program, their housing status at the end of the pilot program, and the use of housing assistance by veterans before and after receiving services. Additionally, an assessment of the employment status of these veterans should be included. The report should assess the employment status of veterans who received case management services under the program, comparing their status before and after receiving services. SEC. 5. EXPANSION OF HOUSING ASSISTANCE PROGRAM OF DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. Section 2041 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to assist homeless veterans, their families, veterans at risk of homelessness, and very low-income veteran families. To assist homeless veterans and their families, veterans at risk of homelessness, and very low-income veteran families in acquiring shelter, transitioning to permanent housing, and maintaining occupancy in permanent housing. To provide permanent or transitional housing for veterans and families described in paragraph (1). The amendment involves ensuring veterans who receive housing also receive referrals for entitled benefits and services under this title. The amendment involves updating the clause regarding veterans and families described in paragraph (1) in chapter 20 of the title. SEC. 6. OUTREACH RELATING TO INCREASING THE AMOUNT OF HOUSING AVAILABLE TO VETERANS. This section pertains to housing assistance for homeless veterans, veterans in temporary housing, and very low-income veteran families. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will collaborate with various entities to conduct outreach to educate them about the housing needs of veterans. Additionally, a National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans will be established. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish the National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans to operate independently and address the housing needs of veterans. The National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans, established by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, operates independently to research causes of veteran homelessness, assess program effectiveness, and share best practices for housing stabilization and support. The Department aims to assess and improve programs for homeless veterans, identify best practices for housing stabilization and support, and integrate evidence-based policies to address veteran homelessness effectively. The Department aims to integrate evidence-based policies and best practices into programs for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. It also serves as a resource center for research and training activities related to veteran homelessness. The Department coordinates research and training activities on veteran homelessness with Federal and non-Federal entities. The Department of Veterans Affairs is improving administrative processes for grant and per diem programs. Section 2012 of title 38, United States Code is amended to include a new subsection (e) for reviewing grant recipients and eligible entities receiving per diem payments for services provided to veterans. The per diem payment under this section evaluates the grant recipient or eligible entity's performance in assisting veterans with housing and increasing their income. The Secretary evaluates grant recipients and eligible entities' performance in assisting veterans with housing and increasing their income to determine continued per diem eligibility. Uniform performance targets are established nationwide for all recipients receiving per diem payments. The Secretary establishes uniform performance targets nationwide for grant recipients and eligible entities receiving per diem payments to evaluate their performance.
